history.content: yes why not? 100% maybe 110% - you can do it and i believe in you fam. i understand what you're feeling. i didn't take any low level stuff (162,164,168) and i'm doing deep learning in industry. hell i didn't even take 188 or 189 lol.

yes why not? 100% maybe 110% idk you can do it. but yes and i believe in you fam. i understand what you're feeling. i didn't take any low level stuff (162,164,168) and i'm doing deep learning in industry. hell i didn't even take 188 or 189 lol.

I surveyed students graduating with an EECS minor (took 4 lower division and 3 upper divisions) and they're doing really similar things to our graduates. It's absolutely possible. I would suggest keeping an eye on our info sessions, and subscribing to the CS Career Mail emails sent out by the career center.

Hello everyone. I'm about to graduate in 2-3 semesters, so I need to start thinking about job prospects and exactly what I want to do with my post-college life. I would like to consider CS and its related fields as potential options, but considering how competitive the job market is right now I'm wondering if that's really viable without a BA/BS in Computer Science (will be getting a BA in Applied Math)

Little Academic Background:

After I took 61A/B and Math 54, I absolutely loved 54 (thought it was extremely cool) but didn't really feel so driven in 61A/B, so decided I did not want to pursue a CS degree and went for an Applied Math degree instead. I didn't take 61C, and I probably am not going to. But I do find AI and ML very interesting, and would like to consider it as a potential career option.

I have taken Stat 133, 134, 135, and will probably take 151A, 153, 154 as well for my Math cluster.

I'm planning on taking CS 189, possibly 188 (I heard getting into that class is pretty difficult if you're not CS), and 170 over the next couple of semesters for the "AI/ML background."

Is it possible or likely for me with my current background to score a job/position in CS or its related fields? I see a lot of postings requiring a CS degree. I don't really want to work as a software engineer (don't even think I can if I wanted to since I lack knowledge in that area). If not, what are some of my options to pursue a career in these fields? Thanks!
history.subject: Non-CS STEM Major Career in CS/Related Fields?
